author: barnabemonnot
content:
i missed the draft! I like the story you weave at the beginning, definitely captured some of my experience when i started with ethereum lol

two comments I have, curious to hear what you think
1) i don't expect "average users" to be on layer 1 in about one to three years from now. if they are doing payments as the coinbase wallet helps them do, they will definitely be on L2. so i don't expect they would even have to set anything but how much they are sending and to whom. but eip1559 isn't just a UX improvement for the average user, it's also one for "power users" e.g., rollups closing their batches on L1 and all the other txs they need to do
2) that said, assuming the user is on L1, I don't even think coinbase wallet would ask them their maximum willingness to pay for the transaction. they could just quote the current price for them, set the max fee to twice the basefee and likely their transactions would go through. the user would only need to decide if they are willing to pay the current gas price. then a metamask user (assumed more knowledgeable than a coinbase one) could have an additional screen when basefee is increasing rapidly where they set their parameters more finely, but even for them a yes/no UX would work well most of the time

author: sky.cactus
content: I suspect we may be talking about different "layer 2"s.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm pretty firmly in the camp that Layer 1 should be a data availability layer, which means all transactions touch layer 1.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are *only* broadcasting your transaction on layer 2 then you have a data availability problem that is actually very hard to solve in a censorship resistant way, and if you do you basically end up authoring another entire blockchain.

author: sky.cactus
content: All transactions should show up on layer 1 IMO, even if *execution* is on layer 2.  That way Ethereum solves the very hard problem of data availability.
